description: Celebrated on the first Monday of September in the US, it honors the contributions of the American workforce and their role in the nation's prosperity. Originating from the late 19th-century labor movement, it symbolizes advancements in work conditions and wages. The holiday marks summer's end with parades and picnics and provides a well-deserved break while highlighting workers' rights and work-life balance.

On September 16, 1810, Miguel Hidalgo y Costilla, known as Father Hidalgo, initiated the call for autonomy, leading to Mexico's Independence Day—a nationally revered occasion. In over two centuries, September 16 has become a widespread celebration in Mexico, commemorating Father Hidalgo's initial advocacy for independence. Worldwide, individuals of Mexican heritage unite to honor their nation's liberation from Spanish rule.
